Sample Outputs: gemini-3-pro-preview

− Iteration 1 — Avg Score: 82.1
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 79.5
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Arthur kept adjusting his collar, unused to the formal attire he was instructed to wear. The synthetic silk chafed against his neck, a tactile reminder that he was far removed from the dust-caked enviro-suits and recycled air of the Chryse Planitia mining sector. He sat in the passenger cabin of a sleek, needle-nosed shuttle, a vessel that hummed with the quiet, arrogant efficiency of expensive engineering. Across from him sat two guards. They wore the slate-grey uniforms of the Antares Diplomatic Corp, complete with the insignia: a stylized red star caught in the mandibles of a silver scorpion. They had not spoken a word since they had escorted Arthur from his hab-unit, bypassing the local magistrate with a frighteningly simple wave of a digital credential. Arthur looked out the viewport. Mars was a receding ochre crescent, the vast web of orbital elevators and corporate docks glittering like diamond dust against the black. "I suppose," Arthur said, his voice sounding thin in the pressurized cabin, "that it would be futile to ask where we are going?" The guard on the left merely blinked. The guard on the right checked a chronometer on his wrist—an analog device, Arthur noted, a affectation of the ultra-wealthy—and said, "We are docking, Mr. Neegan. The Commissioner dislikes tardiness." The shuttle shuddered, a low-frequency thrum vibrating through the floorplates, as it was swallowed by the hangar bay of a much larger vessel. Through the port, Arthur caught a glimpse of the hull: burnished durasteel, bristling with sensor arrays and, more ominously, turrets that were certainly not for diplomatic communication. Minutes later, Arthur was ushered through corridors of muted beige and soft lighting, a stark contrast to the utilitarian corridors of the colony. He was deposited into a room that smelled of old paper and mild tobacco. "Mr. Neegan. Please, sit." The man behind the desk was slight, balding, and possessed a face that seemed to have been eroded by centuries of bureaucratic wind. He wore the sash of a High Commissioner. He did not stand up. Arthur sat in the plush chair, feeling dangerously under-qualified. "I am Arthur Neegan. I am a mining engineer, licensed by the Terran Coalition. I have rights." "We all have rights, in theory," the man said, smiling without showing teeth. "In practice, we have leverage. I am Commissioner Valerius. Welcome to the *Ares Magna*." Valerius tapped a glass surface on his desk. A three-dimensional projection sprang to life—a rotating topographical map of Arthur’s claim in Sector 4. A bright, pulsating violet vein ran through the subterranean layers like a bruised artery. "Azra," Valerius said softly. "Element 124, if the periodic table were still relevant to such anomalies. A substance that does not merely radiate; it encourages its neighbors to do the same. A contagious energy source." "I know what it is," Arthur said, his engineer’s mind taking over his fear. "I know the half-life metrics. I know it can power a hyper-drive for a century on a single gram. That’s why the corporations are swarming my land." "The corporations," Valerius said with a dismissive wave of a manicured hand, "are short-sighted children playing with matches in a powder magazine. They see profit. The Terran Coalition sees a way to break the standoff with the Outer Systems. But the Antares Sector... we see the history of the next thousand years." Arthur leaned forward. "And what does that history look like?" "Volatile," Valerius replied. He stood up and walked to a wall lined with actual books—bound volumes, rare and fragile. "Tell me, Mr. Neegan, as an engineer: what happens if you introduce Azra into a standard fission pile without the proper containment fields?" "The rate of decay accelerates exponentially," Arthur recited. "The reaction becomes instantaneous. It’s not a meltdown; it’s a solar flare in a bottle." "Precisely. Now, imagine that on a planetary scale. Imagine a warhead the size of a walnut that can strip the atmosphere off an inhabited world." Valerius turned back to him. "That is what sits beneath your feet. It is not a gold mine, Mr. Neegan. It is the sword of Damocles." Arthur felt a cold knot tighten in his stomach. "You’re saying the corporations don't know how to handle it?" "I am saying that Global Mining Amalgamated intends to extract it using percussion blasting," Valerius said dryly. "If they do, they will likely trigger a sympathetic resonance in the surrounding bedrock. Mars won't just have a new mine; it will have a new crater the size of the northern hemisphere." Arthur stared at the projection. He knew the geology. He knew the strata. If the Azra vein was as deep as the scan suggested, and if it was indeed piezo-reactive... "They'll crack the crust," Arthur whispered. "And the Terran Coalition will let them," Valerius added, "because they are desperate for the fuel to power their new dreadnaughts. They are blinded by the arms race." "So, you kidnapped me to give me a geology lesson?" "I 'invited' you," Valerius corrected, "to offer you a solution. The Antares Diplomatic Corp has invoked an obscure clause in the Colonial Charter—the Planetary Safety Edict of 2104. We are seizing jurisdiction of your claim, ostensibly for environmental preservation." "You want to steal it," Arthur said flatly. "We want to *manage* it. We possess the technology to extract Azra via harmonic dampening. It is slow, it is expensive, and it is safe. But legally, we cannot touch the land without the owner’s consent, lest we trigger an interplanetary incident with Earth." Valerius slid a data-slate across the mahogany desk. "This grants the Antares Corp exclusive mining rights. In exchange, you remain the titular head of operations. You will be wealthy beyond the dreams of avarice, Mr. Neegan. But more importantly, you will be the man who saved Mars from becoming an asteroid belt." Arthur looked at the slate. It was a heavy document, filled with dense legalese. "And if I refuse? If I go to the Coalition?" "Then you will be a patriot," Valerius shrugged. "A dead patriot, likely. The corporations are not known for their patience, and the Coalition Intelligence Bureau is already wondering why you haven't sold to them yet. They will assume you are holding out for a better price, or that you are a sympathizer with the Separatists. Either way, your life expectancy drops to a statistical error." Arthur looked around the room—the books, the quiet luxury, the silent, terrifying weight of political machinations. He realized then that the mining drills and survey rovers he loved were toys. This—this quiet conversation in a room orbiting a planet—was the real machinery of the galaxy. "It's a tug of war," Arthur said. "Between Earth and the Outer Systems. And I'm the rope." "You are the fulcrum," Valerius corrected. "Where you lean, the galaxy tips." Arthur picked up the stylus. His hand trembled, not from fear, but from the sheer scale of the burden. He thought of the dome lights of Chryse Planitia, the families living under the polycarbonate shells, breathing the air he helped circulate. "Harmonic dampening," Arthur said, looking up. "I want to see the schematics. I want to verify the engineering before I sign." Valerius’s eyes twinkled. It was the first genuine emotion he had shown. "A rational demand. Spoken like a true Spacer. We have the blueprints prepared." Arthur adjusted his collar again. It felt tighter than before, but for the first time, he felt he was growing into the suit. "Show me," Arthur said.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a solid understanding of Asimov's style and the classic sci-fi genre, successfully creating a tense political thriller set in a well-realized future universe. The author effectively captures the retrofuturistic atmosphere with details like analog chronometers as affectations of the wealthy, bound books as luxury items, and the bureaucratic machinery of interplanetary politics. The world-building excels in both macro and micro elements, from the specific technical details of Azra's properties to the broader geopolitical tensions between Earth, Mars colonies, and the Outer Systems. The author demonstrates strong scientific grounding in the discussion of radioactive decay and geological consequences, making the stakes feel both technically plausible and dramatically compelling. Commissioner Valerius emerges as a well-crafted antagonist - urbane, calculating, and genuinely threatening without resorting to melodrama. His casual dismissal of corporations as "children playing with matches" and his matter-of-fact discussion of planetary destruction effectively establishes both his sophistication and ruthlessness. Arthur's characterization as a competent engineer thrust into political machinations feels authentic, and his insistence on seeing the technical schematics provides a satisfying character moment that demonstrates his professional competence. The dialogue carries the narrative effectively, revealing character motivations and advancing plot while maintaining the formal, slightly stilted tone appropriate to diplomatic negotiations. The conversation flows naturally between exposition and character development, though some exchanges lean heavily toward information delivery. The pacing builds tension appropriately, moving from Arthur's disorientation through the revelation of stakes to his cautious acceptance of the situation. The metaphor progression from "tug of war" to "fulcrum" effectively captures Arthur's growing understanding of his position. However, the piece occasionally relies on exposition-heavy dialogue, particularly in Valerius's explanations of Azra's properties and geopolitical implications. While this serves the story's needs, it sometimes feels more like a briefing than natural conversation. The ending, while dramatically satisfying, feels somewhat rushed in Arthur's transition from victim to participant. The prose generally maintains elegance without becoming overwrought, though some phrases like "eroded by centuries of bureaucratic wind" border on the purple. The technical discussions are well-integrated and enhance rather than impede the narrative flow. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 5.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 88.0
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The smell of the darkroom is a specific kind of alchemy—vinegar, wet silver, and the metallic tang of patience. It’s a scent that usually sharpens my focus, makes me feel like a god pulling images out of the void. But tonight, the acetic acid just makes the air feel heavy, thick with words that haven’t been spoken yet. I watched Elliot’s hands as he rocked the developer tray. He has beautiful hands—long, pale fingers adorned with chunky silver rings that clack softly against the plastic. He’s nineteen, a baby by my standards, but he carries an ancient sort of quiet. I’m twenty-five, and I usually eat boys like him for breakfast. Or, I used to. My track record is a gallery of rugged, self-assured men—guys who know exactly what space they take up in the world and dare me to push them out of it. I like the friction. I like the fight. But Elliot isn’t a fight. He’s a riddle written in thrift-store velvet and mesh. "Three minutes," he whispered, his voice barely rising above the hum of the ventilation fan. "I know," I said, leaning back against the counter. I crossed my arms, a defensive posture I didn’t actually feel. "Don't over-agitate it. You want the grain to settle." He looked up, and the red safelight caught the sharp architecture of his cheekbones. He was wearing heavy eyeliner today, smudged intentionally in a way that made him look like a bruised saint. A ripped fishnet shirt peeked out from under his oversized band hoodie. It was a look that screamed *look at me*, but his body language was always *please don’t perceive me*. That contradiction had been itching at my brain for the entire semester. Why was I so drawn to this? I’m the one who initiates. I’m the one who pins a guy against the wall at a bar. With Elliot, I felt like I was walking through a museum where I wasn't allowed to touch the art. "Dani?" "Yeah?" "I think I messed up the exposure on the negative," he said, his voice trembling slightly. "The shadows look too deep." I pushed off the counter and moved next to him. The room was small, designed for one person, really. Standing this close, I could smell him over the chemicals—clove cigarettes and something floral, like rosewater. "Let me see," I said, my shoulder brushing his. He flinched, just a fraction, but didn't pull away. I peered into the tray where the image was ghosting into existence. It was a portrait I’d taken of him last week for our final project on 'Distortion and Identity.' We’d used a slow shutter speed while he moved, creating a blur that looked like his soul was trying to escape his body. "It's not too deep," I corrected him, my voice dropping an octave, softer than I intended. "It's moody. It’s exactly what we talked about." He kept staring at the swirling liquid. "It looks... trapped." The air shifted. The red light makes everything feel timeless, like the world outside the heavy revolving door doesn't exist. It’s a confessional booth. "Trapped how?" I asked, turning my body fully toward him. Elliot let go of the tray. The liquid settled. He didn't look at me; he looked at his hands, twisting a silver ring shaped like a skull. "I don't know if I like seeing myself," he said. "Like, *him*." He gestured vaguely at the photo of himself. "He looks so... solid. So defined." My heart did a strange, stuttering thing. I’m used to taking charge, to reading the room and driving the conversation, but here, I felt like I needed to hold my breath. "Defined isn't always good?" I prompted, careful. Gentle. Not my usual setting. "I don't think I want to be defined like that anymore," he murmured. He finally looked up, his eyes wide and dark in the crimson gloom. "I’ve been... I’ve been thinking about the way I present. The way I take up space. I don't think 'he' fits right now. Or maybe not just 'he'." He looked terrified. He looked like he was handing me a grenade and waiting to see if I’d pull the pin. My phone buzzed against my hip—sharp, insistent. Probably my ex, or a party invite, or the noise of the life I usually lead. I didn't even twitch. I let it buzz until it died, refusing to break the circuit between Elliot’s eyes and mine. A dozen instincts fired at once. The protective instinct flared hot and bright—I wanted to wrap him up, shield him from the assholes in the sculpture department who made fun of his nail polish. But there was also confusion. I like men. I like the binary friction of *man* and *woman*. If Elliot was drifting away from that shore, where did that leave me? Where did that leave this magnetic pull that had me staying late in the darkroom on a Friday night? But looking at him, vulnerable and shivering slightly in the climate-controlled air, the labels didn't seem to matter as much as the person trembling in front of me. "Okay," I said. I kept my hands to myself, though I desperately wanted to reach out and fix his collar, to touch his face. That was my urge to control, and I had to strangle it. He needed agency, not a savior. "That makes sense, Elliot. Looking at your work... looking at *you* this semester. It makes sense." He let out a breath that sounded like a sob. "You don't think it's stupid? That I'm just... confused?" "I think you're the most intentional person I know," I said firmly. The assertiveness bled back in, but this time it was in service of him. "There is nothing stupid about shedding a skin that doesn't fit." He smiled then, a small, fragile thing that hit me harder than a shot of whiskey. The chemistry in the room spiked, no longer just intellectual but visceral. I looked at his lips—soft, painted dark—and realized that my "type" was a lie I told myself to keep things simple. There was nothing simple about this. "I bought a skirt," he confessed, the words rushing out now that the dam had cracked. "A long one. Linen. I haven't worn it out of my room yet." "Bring it next time," I said, the command coming naturally. "We’ll shoot it. We’ll do a session. Just us. No grades. Just so you can see what you look like when you aren't hiding." He looked at me with a mixture of awe and relief. "You'd do that?" "I'm the photographer, Elliot. My job is to capture the truth." I stepped closer, invading his space just enough to test the waters. "And I really want to see you. The real you." The tension was thick, a physical weight. In the red light, gender felt fluid, dissolved by the chemicals and the shadows. I wasn't just the older, assertive woman, and he wasn't just the shy, younger boy. We were just two people in the dark, waiting to see what developed. "The timer," he whispered, though he didn't move to check it. "Let it sit," I said, my voice low. "It needs a little more time." He nodded, his gaze dropping to my lips before flickering back up. He didn't step back. For the first time, I didn't know what was going to happen next, and for the first time, I didn't want to control the outcome. I just wanted to be there when the image finally became clear.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and emotional intelligence in handling a delicate, contemporary subject matter. The narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective with authentic internal conflict and growth, while treating Elliot's gender questioning with sensitivity and nuance. The darkroom setting functions effectively as both literal space and metaphor, creating an intimate confessional atmosphere that justifies the vulnerability and revelations. The author skillfully uses the photography process as a parallel to personal development and self-discovery, with the chemical processes and image development serving as organic metaphors rather than forced symbolism. Characterization is particularly strong. Dani's voice feels authentic - her usual assertiveness genuinely complicated by unfamiliar territory, creating believable internal tension between her instinct to take charge and her recognition that Elliot needs agency. The portrayal avoids stereotypes while acknowledging the complexity of attraction and identity. Elliot emerges as a full character despite limited dialogue, with his vulnerability feeling earned rather than manipulative. The prose strikes an effective balance between literary sophistication and accessibility. Phrases like "ancient sort of quiet" and "riddle written in thrift-store velvet and mesh" are evocative without becoming overwrought. The sensory details of the darkroom environment are well-integrated and purposeful. The dialogue, while sparse, rings true to the characters and situation. The conversations feel naturally awkward and tentative, appropriate to the emotional stakes and Elliot's vulnerability. The emotional complexity is handled with maturity - Dani's confusion about her own identity and attraction patterns feels psychologically realistic, as does her protective instinct. The piece avoids easy answers while providing emotional satisfaction through connection and understanding rather than resolution. The ending maintains appropriate restraint, focusing on mutual recognition and possibility rather than rushing toward romantic fulfillment or dramatic transformation. This feels earned and honest to the characters' emotional state. Minor weaknesses include occasional slight repetitiveness in describing Dani's usual relationship patterns, and some metaphors that border on precious, though they generally stay within acceptable bounds. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 80.9
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**The Collision** The screech of rubber against cobblestone was violent enough to silence the pigeons, if not the tourists. Ben, clutching a dog-eared copy of *Lonely Planet: Rome* like a holy relic, froze in the middle of the narrow street near the Trevi Fountain. Inches from his shins, the front wheel of a battered red Vespa hissed to a halt. "Ma sei pazzo?" The rider pushed up her visor, revealing eyes the color of espresso and a glare that could curdle milk. "Do you have a death wish, or are you just trying to test my brakes?" Ben adjusted his glasses, which sat askew on his nose. "I—I’m frightfully sorry. I was just looking for the Pantheon and the map is distinctly unhelpful regarding the one-way systems." Alessandra killed the engine, the silence ringing louder than the noise. She looked him up and down: tweed jacket in June, sensible shoes, an aura of terminal politeness. A British academic in the wild. "The Pantheon is that way," she said, pointing aggressively behind her. "You are walking toward the river. And you are standing in the middle of a loading zone." "Right. Yes. Stupid of me." Ben stepped back onto the curb, tripping slightly over his own feet. "I’m Ben. Sabbatical. History of Art." Alessandra straddled the bike, balancing the courier box on the back with practiced ease. She tilted her head, a sudden, wolfish grin replacing the scowl. She saw the way he clutched the book, the nervous flutter of his hands. He was pristine, boring, and entirely too safe. She wanted to see what he looked like a little messed up. "I am Alessandra," she said, her voice dropping an octave. "And you owe me for the wear on my brake pads." "Oh. I have Euros, somewhere..." He began patting his pockets. "Keep your money, Englishman," she laughed, kicking the kickstand up. "Get on." *** **The Detour** "This is not the way to the Pantheon!" Ben shouted over the roar of the engine and the wind whipping past his ears. "Correct!" Alessandra yelled back, weaving between a Mercedes and a fruit cart with terrifying precision. They were miles from the tourist center now, tearing through the gritty, graffiti-stained streets of Testaccio. Ben’s arms were wrapped tight around Alessandra’s waist—a necessity for survival, he told himself, though he was acutely aware of the heat radiating from her leather jacket and the smell of her perfume: jasmine and gasoline. She parked abruptly outside a dusty antique shop that looked closed. "Why are we here?" Ben asked, his hair now a windblown disaster. "I have a delivery. You are my assistant. Don't speak Italian. It offends the ears." Inside, the shop smelled of old paper and beeswax. While Alessandra argued rapidly with the proprietor—a withered man who looked like he was carved from olive wood—Ben wandered the aisles. He watched Alessandra out of the corner of his eye. She was animated, her hands flying, her smile dazzling the old man. Ben saw the moment it happened. It was like a magic trick. Alessandra leaned over the counter to inspect a porcelain figurine. As she laughed at something the man said, her left hand dropped to a tray of silver trinkets. With a movement fluid as water, a small, ornate silver snuff box vanished up her sleeve. Ben blinked. He looked at her face; she was the picture of innocence. When they walked out, the old man waving happily, Alessandra tossed the package into her bike’s box. "Did you..." Ben started, his voice hushed. "That silver box. You took it." Alessandra mounted the bike, looking at him with hooded amusement. She didn't deny it. She didn't return it. She just winked. "Stolen moments are the sweetest, Ben. Are you coming, or are you walking?" Ben looked at the shop, then at the woman who was currently shattering every rule of conduct he held dear. A thrill, cold and electric, shot down his spine. He climbed on the bike. *** **The Gelato Shop** The sky bruised purple and opened up without warning. It wasn't a sprinkle; it was a Roman deluge, turning the cobblestones into slick rivers. They scrambled off the bike, dashing under the striped awning of a closed gelato shop near Piazza Navona. They were pressed against the glass, shoulder to shoulder, the rain creating a curtain of gray water inches from their noses. Alessandra shook her head like a wet dog, sending droplets flying onto Ben’s already soaked jacket. She was laughing, breathless and alive. "Look at you," she teased, reaching out to fix his collar. Her fingers grazed his neck, warm against the rain-chilled skin. "You look like a drowned rat, Professor." "And you look like the one who drowned him," Ben retorted, surprised by his own boldness. Alessandra paused, her hand lingering on his lapel. The air between them grew heavy, charged with the humidity and the adrenaline of the day’s crimes. She had dragged him through illegal U-turns, stolen a snuff box, and convinced him to lie to a traffic cop about being a diplomat. "You liked it," she whispered, stepping closer. There was nowhere for him to retreat; his back was against the glass. "The stealing. The speed. You aren't as good as you pretend to be." "I'm terrified of you," Ben admitted, his voice rough. "Good." She reached into her jacket pocket. Ben expected the snuff box. Instead, she pulled out a pair of vintage sunglasses he had admired at a street stall three hours ago. The vendor had been distracted by a shouting match nearby. Ben hadn't seen her take them. She slid the glasses onto Ben’s face, obscuring his eyes. "Keep them," she said softly. "They make you look dangerous." Ben stood there, blinded by the dark lenses in the dim rain, his heart hammering against his ribs. He knew he should hand them back. He knew he should lecture her on morality. Instead, he touched the frame, accepting the complicity. *** **The Parting** The rain stopped as quickly as it had begun, leaving the city glistening and steaming. Alessandra dropped him off at the bottom of the Spanish Steps, the sun setting in a blaze of orange behind the Vatican. The engine idled. The vibration hummed through the soles of Ben’s shoes. "Well," Ben said, feeling an unfamiliar ache in his chest. "I suppose I should go write this down in my journal. Though I doubt anyone would believe it." Alessandra didn't take off her helmet. She revved the engine once, a growl of mechanical impatience. "Don't write it down, Ben. Just remember it." "Will I see you again?" "Rome is a small village," she said enigmatically. "Check your pockets." Before he could ask what she meant, she peeled away, the Vespa becoming a red blur weaving through the evening traffic, leaving him in a cloud of exhaust. Ben stood there for a long moment, the chaos of the city rushing back in around him. He reached into his jacket pocket. The silver snuff box was there. Cold and heavy. He gasped, looking around guiltily, then pulled it out. Inside, tucked into the velvet lining, was a scrap of paper torn from a delivery invoice. On it, scrawled in black marker, was a phone number and a single sentence: *I’m coming back for the silver. Be ready.* Ben looked at the stolen silver, then at the sunglasses in his other hand. A slow, wide smile broke across his face, cracking his scholarly reserve wide open. He pocketed the evidence and walked into the Roman night, no longer looking for the Pantheon.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and adheres closely to the prompt requirements. The author successfully creates four interconnected scenes spanning a day in Rome, featuring the requested characters with their distinct personalities - Alessandra as the fiery, mischievous motorcycle courier with kleptomaniac tendencies, and Ben as the polite, bumbling British academic. The characterization is particularly effective. Alessandra emerges as genuinely dangerous and alluring, her kleptomania woven naturally into the narrative without heavy-handed exposition. The author shows rather than tells her nature through actions like the snuff box theft and her casual amorality. Ben's transformation from uptight academic to willing accomplice feels organic, driven by his fascination with Alessandra rather than arbitrary plot necessity. The dialogue captures the cultural clash effectively, with Alessandra's sharp wit ("Ma sei pazzo?") contrasting Ben's stammering politeness. The prose maintains a consistent cinematic quality throughout, with vivid sensory details like "jasmine and gasoline" and "eyes the color of espresso" that ground the reader in the Roman setting without becoming overwrought. The structure works well, with each scene building tension and intimacy. The rain sequence serves as an effective emotional climax, creating physical proximity that mirrors their growing connection. The kleptomania subplot pays off cleverly in the ending, with the snuff box exchange creating a perfect circular structure and promise of continuation. However, some elements feel slightly predictable - the "opposites attract" dynamic and the reformed academic trope are familiar territory. The piece also occasionally veers toward romantic fantasy rather than psychological realism, particularly in how quickly Ben accepts criminal behavior. Some descriptions, while evocative, border on cliché ("eyes the color of espresso"). The ending strikes the right balance of resolution and open possibility. The note in the snuff box provides closure while maintaining the story's playful, dangerous energy. Ben's transformation feels earned through the accumulated experiences rather than sudden personality shift. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 5.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 85.0
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The amber liquid in Old Doran’s glass tilts three degrees to the left, holds there for a gravity-defying second, and then sloshes violently back to the right. A splash of cheap synthetic ale hits the scarred countertop. "Damned stabilizers," Doran grumbles, wiping the foam from his grey beard. "Tell the station chief to divert power from the atmospheric scrubbers. I’d rather breathe stale air than spill good booze." I toss a rag over the spill, wiping it down with practiced efficiency. "You’re drinking *Rust Bucket* ale, Doran. Calling it 'good booze' is a crime against fermentation. And if I divert power from the scrubbers, we all suffocate by morning. Then who’s going to listen to you complain about your ex-wives?" Doran chuckles, the sound rattling in his chest. "You would, Nets. You love the drama. It’s your tragic flaw. You can’t help but stick your nose in the muck." "My nose is perfectly fine, thank you," I say, checking the levels on the tap. "And my flaw is that I’m too generous with my pouring hand. Which is why you’re still sitting here." "That," a melodic, buzzing voice chimes in from the end of the bar, "and the fact that you are hiding from the law, and we are the only ones who do not care." I shoot a glare at Xylia. She’s an insectoid mechanic with a carapace that gleams like oil on water. She’s polishing a lug nut with a napkin. "I am not hiding from the law," I correct her, leaning my elbows on the bar. "I am *retired* from a high-stress sector. There is a difference. Besides, out here in the belt, 'law' is just a suggestion made by people with bigger guns." "Speaking of guns," Doran says, tapping his empty glass. "Refill?" "Put it on the tab," I sigh, reaching for the tap. The gravity fluctuates again. The bottles on the back shelf chime together like wind chimes in a gale. It’s the Andromeda drift; this station, *The Last Outpost*, is barely held together by spit and outdated mag-locks. It’s a dump, but it’s warm, it smells like ozone and cinnamon, and nobody asks for your ID if you pay in hard credits. The pneumatic hiss of the main airlock door cuts through the low hum of conversation. The ambient chatter—miners discussing vein yields, merchants arguing over hyper-lane taxes—doesn't stop, but the volume drops a decibel. Instinct. Everyone here is running from something; we all listen for the heavy boots of enforcement. But the boots aren't heavy. They’re stumbling. A figure shuffles toward the bar. He’s a Ceph-human hybrid, his skin a mottled grey. His most striking feature, usually a point of pride for his species, is the mass of tentacled dreadlocks cascading from his scalp. Right now, they are twitching erratically, knotted and dry. He looks like he hasn't slept since he left the Core Systems. He collapses onto the stool next to Doran, who instinctively scoots six inches away. The stranger looks up. His eyes are wide, the pupils dilating rhythmically. "Vega whisky, neat," he rasps. "Better make that a double." I don't move immediately. I analyze. Dust on his coat—red silica. He’s been on the surface of LV-426 or somewhere similar. No visible weapon, but his hand is clutching the inside of his jacket pocket so tight his knuckles are white. "We only have the synthetic stuff," I say softly. "Real Vega requires a clearance license I burned three years ago." "Synthetic is fine," he snaps, his voice cracking. "Just... pour it. Please." I grab a clean glass—one of the heavy ones that doesn't tip over when the gravity glitches—and pour a generous measure of the amber liquid. I slide it across the wood. He downs half of it in one gulp. He shudders, the tentacles on his head curling tight against his skull. "Rough trip?" I ask, keeping my tone light, the casual bartender banter that disarms the paranoid. He stares at the glass. "You could say that." "You’re new to the Belt," I state. It’s not a question. "Your bio-suit is too clean, and you’re drinking Vega like it’s water. Vega is for celebrating or forgetting. Which is it?" He looks at me then. Really looks at me. His eyes dart to the scar running along my jawline, then to the tattoo of the thorny net on my wrist—the one that gave me my nickname. "Forgetting," he whispers. "I need to forget I ever saw it." Doran leans in, his curiosity overriding his survival instinct. "Saw what, son? A ghost ship? A claim jumper?" The stranger laughs, a hollow, wet sound. "I wish. Ghosts don't leave paper trails." My stomach tightens. *Paper trails.* That’s corporate talk. That’s Core talk. "Hey," I say, lowering my voice. I grab a rag and start wiping the counter directly in front of him, forcing proximity. "If you’re in trouble with a Corp, you need to keep your voice down. The walls here have ears, and the ears sell information for spare parts." The stranger leans in, the smell of ozone and fear rolling off him. "I’m not just in trouble. I’m dead. I just haven't stopped moving yet." "We don't do dead here," I say firmly. "We do lost. We do found. We do drunk. Who is chasing you?" He takes another sip, his hand shaking so hard the liquid ripples. "Have you ever heard of the Chimera Project?" I freeze. My hand stops moving the rag. The bar seems to tilt, but this time, the gravity stabilizers are perfectly steady. It’s just me. "Xylia," I call out, not looking away from the stranger. "Check the comms array. Make sure we’re running on the closed loop." Xylia’s mandibles click. She senses the shift in my tone. "On it, Nets." "I didn't think anyone out here knew the name," the stranger murmurs, watching my reaction. "I know a lot of things I shouldn't," I say. "That’s why I pour drinks on a rock floating in the ass-end of the galaxy. If you’re carrying data from Chimera, you didn't just bring heat to my bar, pal. You brought an incinerator." "I didn't steal data," he hisses, leaning closer, his tentacles writhing. "I stole the key." He slowly pulls his hand out of his jacket. He isn't holding a gun. He’s holding a small, crystalline cube, pulsing with a faint, violet light. It hums, a sound that seems to vibrate in my teeth. Doran whistles low. "Pretty. What’s it do?" "It opens the containment vaults on the Prime Sector," the stranger says. "And it’s tracking me. I thought the asteroid interference would mask the signal." "It won't," I say, my heart hammering against my ribs. I know that tech. I helped design the security protocols that guard it, back in a life I tried to bury under cheap whiskey and bad jokes. "That crystal operates on quantum entanglement. Distance doesn't matter. Interference doesn't matter." "Then they know I'm here," he whispers, the color draining from his face. "They knew you were here before you ordered the drink," I say grimly. Suddenly, the station’s lights flicker. The hum of the air recyclers dies, plunging the bar into a sudden, oppressive silence. The gravity fails completely for a second—everyone floats a few inches off their stools, liquids turning into floating spheres—before slamming back on with double the force. Glasses shatter. Doran yelps as he hits the floor. Red emergency lights begin to strobe, bathing the bar in a bloody pulse. "Attention," a computerized voice booms, bypassing the local audio and vibrating the hull itself. It’s not the station AI. It’s a military-grade override. "This station is now under interdiction by the Aethelgard Corporation. Surrender the fugitive, or we will vent the atmosphere." The stranger looks at me, terrified. "You said this was a home." I reach under the bar, my fingers brushing past the bottle of Vega and wrapping around the cold handle of the pulse-shotgun I swore I’d never use again. "It is," I say, racking the slide. The sound is loud in the sudden quiet. "And nobody vents my home." I look at Xylia. "Kill the main door locks. Doran, get behind the bar. You," I point the shotgun barrel at the stranger. "Keep that crystal hidden. If they see it, they won't bother negotiating." "What are you going to do?" the stranger asks, trembling. "I'm going to negotiate," I say, stepping out from behind the bar. "But first, I need to know one thing. What is *actually* in those vaults? Because Aethelgard doesn't besiege a station for money." The stranger swallows hard. "They aren't vaults, Nets. They're incubators." The red light pulses. The airlock cycles. Someone is coming in. "Well," I mutter, aiming at the door. "There goes my tip."
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This is a well-executed piece of cozy sci-fi that successfully establishes the world, characters, and central conflict while adhering closely to the prompt requirements. The author creates a lived-in feeling space station bar populated with distinctive characters, each with their own voice and mannerisms. The worldbuilding is efficient and immersive, using concrete details like "red silica dust," "gravity stabilizers," and "quantum entanglement" to ground the reader in this universe without overwhelming exposition. The setting feels authentic - a ramshackle outpost where outcasts gather, complete with failing systems and the constant threat of corporate interference. Character development is strong, particularly for protagonist Nets, who emerges as competent, witty, and harboring secrets that connect to the unfolding crisis. Her voice is consistent throughout - sardonic but caring, experienced but not jaded. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes: revealing character, advancing plot, and building tension. Each character has a distinct speaking pattern, from Doran's gruff complaints to Xylia's formal, buzzing observations. The pacing builds effectively from mundane bar conversation to mounting tension as the stranger arrives and reveals his dangerous cargo. The author successfully establishes conflict without resolving it, ending on a cliffhanger that promises greater stakes ahead. The revelation about "incubators" rather than "vaults" provides an ominous final twist. Technical execution is solid with good sentence flow and vivid imagery. The prose strikes an appropriate balance - descriptive enough to be immersive without becoming overwrought. The dialogue percentage appears to meet the requested 60% ratio, and the word count seems appropriate for the scope. Some minor weaknesses include moments where the worldbuilding exposition feels slightly heavy-handed, and the stranger's character could be more distinctive beyond his obvious terror. The corporate threat, while effectively menacing, follows somewhat familiar sci-fi tropes. However, these don't significantly detract from an otherwise engaging opening chapter. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 84.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**12%.** The number sits in the corner of my screen like a death sentence. Twelve percent battery life. No charger. No outlet. Just me, a backpack that smells like my closet, and the humid, suffocating air of New Orleans. The trucker who dropped me off—a guy named Earl who chewed unlit cigars and listened to talk radio about impending civil war—didn't say goodbye. He just unlocked the passenger door and grunted, "End of the line, kid." So here I am. Canal Street. It’s louder than Tennessee. That’s the first thing that hits me. In my hometown, noise is specific: a lawnmower, a barking dog, a pickup truck backfiring. Here, the noise is a solid wall. It’s brass instruments bleeding out of open doorways, the rattle of streetcars, the drunken shouts of tourists who think wearing plastic beads at 2:00 PM is a personality trait. I tighten the straps of my backpack. My chest binder is digging into my ribs, a familiar, dull ache that usually grounds me, but today it just feels like a cage. I’m sweating. Not a glow, not a mist—I am drenched in a way that makes my oversized flannel shirt stick to my back. *Smart move, Taylor. Run away to a swamp in the middle of July.* I start walking because standing still feels like waiting to be caught. I check the phone again. **11%.** I need to text someone. But who? Mom? *“Hey, sorry I stole forty dollars from the emergency jar and hitched a ride with a conspiracy theorist. Also, sorry I’m not your daughter. Hope the casserole didn’t burn.”* The memory of two days ago rises up like bile. The kitchen table. The silence that stretched so thin I thought it would snap and take my head off. Mom’s face, crumpling like wet paper. Dad, staring at the wall, refusing to look at me, refusing to see the son standing right there in front of him. *“It’s a phase, Taylor. It’s just… those friends of yours online.”* I shove the phone into my pocket. I can’t think about it. If I think about it, I’ll start crying right here in front of a strip club, and I have a reputation to uphold. Even if that reputation is currently "runaway disaster human." I drift toward the French Quarter because that’s where the people are. Safety in numbers, right? Or maybe it’s just easier to hide when everyone else is looking at the architecture. The buildings are beautiful, I guess—iron balconies, peeling paint, ferns hanging like green hair. But the smell is rotting fruit and stale beer. My stomach growls. I have thirty-two dollars left. I buy a bag of Zapp’s chips and a Gatorade from a corner store that looks like it doubles as a crime scene. The clerk doesn't even look up from his phone. I find a bench in Jackson Square. There’s a fortune teller nearby with a table draped in purple velvet, and a guy painting a landscape that looks nothing like the landscape. "You're sitting on my office." I jump, nearly dropping my Gatorade. Sitting on the ground behind the bench, hidden by the wrought iron, is a kid. He looks about my age, maybe a year older. He’s wearing a denim vest covered in patches that look hand-sewn with dental floss. His hair is a chaotic mess of black dye and bleach, and he’s got a safety pin through his earlobe. "I... what?" I stammer. " The bench," he says. He has a slow, drawling voice, but his eyes are sharp. They’re scanning me—shoes to hairline—in a way that makes me want to check if my fly is open. "I sleep under it. I sit on it. It's the office." "I don't see a nameplate," I snap back. The sarcasm is a reflex. It’s how I survived high school. The kid smirks. It transforms his face from scary to mischievous. "Name's Jax. Now you know." "Taylor," I say, before I can stop myself. *First rule of running away: Don't use your real name, idiot.* Jax shifts, pulling a battered pack of cigarettes from his vest. He offers one. I shake my head. "Suit yourself," he says, lighting up. "You look fresh. Like, 'just fell off the turnip truck' fresh." "I'm not fresh," I lie. "I've been... around." "Uh-huh. And that backpack is full of what? Textbooks? A teddy bear?" "Clothes," I say defensively. "And essentials." "Essentials," Jax mocks gently. "Like a toothbrush and hope?" He’s annoying. But he’s talking to me, and he doesn't seem to care that I look like a boy who hasn't quite figured out the edges of himself yet. "Where you from, Taylor?" "Tennessee." "Ouch. My condolences." He exhales a cloud of smoke. "I'm from here. Mostly. Or Mississippi. Depends on who's asking and if they have a warrant." I look at him sharply. "A warrant?" Jax waves a hand dismissively, but I see a flicker of something dark in his expression. A tightness around his jaw. "Figure of speech. Look, you got a place to crash?" "I'm working on it." "That means no. And you got money?" "Some." "That means not enough." Jax stubs out the cigarette on the sole of his boot. "NOLA eats fresh meat, Taylor. Especially after dark. The Quarter is fun and games until the tourists pass out, then the rats come out. And I don't mean the rodents." I check my phone. **6%.** The panic spikes in my chest again. "My phone is dying," I say, my voice sounding smaller than I want it to. "I need a charge." Jax looks at the phone, then at me. He seems to be weighing something. "I know a spot. It’s a squat, couple blocks over. abandoned laundromat. We rigged some power from the streetlamp. It’s sketchy, but it’s dry." "We?" "Me and... some others. Misfit toys." He stands up. He’s taller than me, lanky and jagged. "You coming, or are you gonna wait for the cops to pick you up for curfew violation?" My heart hammers against my ribs. My mom’s voice is in my head: *Stranger danger, Taylor. Don't trust people who look like they haven't showered.* But Mom isn't here. Mom is two states away, probably crying over baby photos of a girl who doesn't exist anymore. "Why would you help me?" I ask. Jax shrugs, adjusting his vest. I notice a bruise blooming purple on his neck, just above the collar. He pulls the fabric up to hide it. "Because I know the look," he says quietly. "The 'I just blew up my life and I don't know how to put the pieces back together' look." He turns and starts walking toward the edge of the square. I look at my phone. **4%.** The sun is starting to dip, casting long, distorted shadows across the pavement. The jazz music sounds frantic now, discordant. I have two choices: Stay here, alone, in the dark, with a dead phone and a history of bad decisions. Or follow the kid with the safety pin in his ear and the secrets under his collar. "Hey," I call out. Jax stops and looks back. "Does the laundromat have a vending machine?" Jax grins, a real, crooked smile. "Nah. But we got a half-eaten box of crackers if you're desperate." I hitch my backpack up. It feels lighter, just by a fraction. "Lead the way," I say. As we walk out of the tourist trap and into the grittier side streets, my phone buzzes one last time in my hand. A text from Mom. I don't read it. I watch the screen fade to black, the little white apple disappearing into the void. Power off. "So," Jax says, kicking a soda can into the gutter. "Tennessee. You run from the law or the Lord?" "Neither," I say, stepping over a puddle of something unrecognizable. "I ran from the truth. Or maybe to it. I haven't decided yet." Jax nods, like that makes perfect sense. "Welcome to New Orleans, Taylor. We're all running from something." I walk beside him, my shoulder brushing his arm, and for the first time in forty-eight hours, the noise in my head quiets down just enough for me to breathe.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements, successfully capturing Taylor's voice as a 16-year-old trans runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The author effectively employs first-person mixed tense narration and incorporates both internal monologue and dialogue as requested. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Taylor's voice feels authentically teenage - sarcastic, vulnerable, and defensive in turns. The internal contradictions are believable: wanting independence while feeling lost, using humor to deflect pain, and the constant tension between bravado and genuine fear. Jax emerges as a compelling secondary character with hints of his own backstory (the bruise, the evasive comments about warrants) that feel organic rather than forced. The prose quality is consistently strong throughout. The opening with the dying phone battery immediately establishes stakes and Taylor's precarious situation. Sensory details effectively establish the New Orleans setting - the wall of sound, the oppressive humidity, the smells of rotting fruit and stale beer. The author avoids purple prose while maintaining vivid imagery. Dialogue feels natural and age-appropriate. The banter between Taylor and Jax establishes character dynamics efficiently, with Jax's streetwise drawl contrasting with Taylor's defensive sarcasm. The conversation flows organically and serves multiple purposes - character development, world-building, and plot advancement. The emotional complexity is handled with sophistication. Taylor's grief over family rejection, anxiety about survival, and cautious hope when meeting Jax creates layered emotional terrain. The piece doesn't shy away from the genuine danger and vulnerability of Taylor's situation while finding moments of connection and possibility. The pacing is well-controlled, moving from Taylor's immediate disorientation through gradual acclimatization to the decision to trust Jax. The phone's dying battery serves as an effective ticking clock that adds urgency without feeling contrived. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought ("the silence that stretched so thin I thought it would snap and take my head off"), though these are infrequent. The ending, while hopeful, feels earned given Taylor's desperation and Jax's genuine understanding of runaway life. The piece successfully balances multiple challenging elements: authentic teenage voice, LGBTQ+ themes, urban danger, and character development within the confines of a single day's narrative. It creates genuine investment in Taylor's journey and establishes compelling dynamics for future chapters. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 77.8
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The end of the world had not arrived with a bang, nor a whimper, but rather with a generic *Terms of Service* update that nobody read, followed shortly by the collective realization that nobody knew how to grow a potato without Googling it first. Midas sat on a crate of what used to be gluten-free crackers, staring at the map. The map was actually a placemat from a diner called *Denny’s*, but in the post-technological landscape—an era historians might have called the "Great Oops" had there been any historians left—it served a navigational purpose. "We need double-As," Midas said, his voice gravelly from an excess of breathing unfiltered air and a lack of proper hydration. "The flashlight is dead. If the flashlight is dead, the darkness wins. And you know what lives in the darkness, Chewy." Chewy sat on the table. Chewy was a *Koala-Kuddle™* unit, a remnant of a simpler time when parents believed their children needed robot marsupials to learn about empathy. His synthetic fur was matted into the texture of a scouring pad, and his left ear hung by a single, tenacious wire. Chewy did not speak. His vocal processor had been damaged during the Incident at the Vending Machine three months prior. Instead, his large, glassy eyes flickered with internal LEDs. They glowed a soft, pulsating *Chartreuse*. "I don't know what Chartreuse means, Chewy," Midas sighed, rubbing his temples. "Is it fear? Hunger? Or is it just a short circuit caused by the humidity?" The eyes shifted to a flat, unamused *Beige*. "Fine. Indifference. I get it." Midas stood up, his knees popping like bubble wrap. "The mission is simple. We go to the Electronics Boutique in the skeleton of the Mall. We locate the batteries. We avoid the feral Roombas. We return. We have light. Simple." It is a well-known fact of the universe that as soon as the word "simple" is uttered, the Gods of Causality roll up their sleeves, spit on their hands, and get to work. *** The Mall was a cathedral of commerce, now reclaimed by nature and aggressive mold. Vines strangled the mannequins in the window of *The Gap*, giving them the appearance of eco-friendly zombies. Midas walked with the cautious gait of a man who has stepped on a rake more times than statistical probability should allow. Chewy rode in Midas’s backpack, facing backward, acting as a rear gunner. Not that Chewy had a gun. He had a terrifying stare and a hard plastic nose that could be used as a bludgeon in a pinch. "Coast looks clear," Midas whispered, stepping over a skeleton clutching a bag of potting soil. "Too clear." They reached the Electronics Boutique. The glass was shattered, diamonds of safety glass crunching under Midas’s mismatched boots. The shelves had been picked clean of the good stuff—gaming consoles, smartwatches, toaster ovens—but the small, boring essentials were often overlooked by looters who prioritized resale value over survival utility. "Jackpot," Midas breathed. There, behind a counter labeled *Geek Squad*, sat a blister pack of AA batteries. They were dusty. They were old. They were beautiful. Midas reached out. Chewy’s eyes flashed a violent, strobing *Red*. "What? What is it?" Midas froze. *Click.* The sound came from beneath Midas’s boot. It was the distinct, mechanical click of a pressure plate. Not a landmine—those were rare. This was worse. It was a *Loss Prevention System*. Despite the total collapse of the power grid, the localized solar backup for the store’s anti-theft system had, through a miracle of engineering that nobody had asked for, survived. "Welcome to Electronics Boutique," a voice boomed from a hidden speaker, cheerful and deafening. "It looks like you are trying to make a purchase! Would you like to sign up for our Rewards Program?" "No," Midas shouted, trying to lift his foot. "Incorrect input!" the voice chirped. "To proceed, please scan your Member ID." "I don't have a Member ID! Civilization has fallen!" "I found three accounts linked to that tone of voice. Are you... *Steve?*" Suddenly, a gate slammed down over the exit. It wasn't a heavy iron gate; it was a flimsy aluminum shutter designed to deter teenagers, but to Midas, it might as well have been the gates of the Underworld. "Chewy, do something!" Chewy’s eyes cycled through the rainbow—Blue (Sadness), Green (Envy), Purple (Existential Dread)—before settling on a blinding *White*. The Koala launched himself from the backpack. He didn't attack the gate. He didn't attack the speaker. He attacked the source of the problem: the receipt printer. The machine was trying to print a coupon for 10% off a strategy guide for a game that no longer existed. Chewy jammed his fuzzy, animatronic arm into the paper feed. "Paper Jam!" the voice screamed, losing its cheerfulness. "Paper Jam in Sector Four! Assistance required! Manager override!" "Grab the batteries!" Midas yelled, diving over the counter as the ceiling sprinklers, confused by the chaos, decided that now was the perfect time to deploy twenty years of stagnant, rusty water. Midas snatched the blister pack. The water hit him like a sledgehammer of sludge. He slipped on the wet tile, performed a pirouette that would have scored high marks in interpretive dance, and crashed into a display of wireless routers. The impact dislodged the pressure plate. The shutter began to rise, stuttering. "Run, Steve! Run!" the machine bellowed, its voice distorting into a demonic baritone as its battery reserves failed. Midas grabbed Chewy by the scruff of his synthetic neck. The Koala’s eyes were now spinning spirals of *Yellow* and *Pink*, indicating that he was either having a seizure or enjoying the ride. They scrambled under the rising gate just as it decided to give up and slam back down, catching the heel of Midas’s left boot and ripping it clean off. *** The walk home was less of a march and more of a hobble. Midas was soaked in ancient sprinkler water that smelled of copper and dead dreams. He was missing a boot, meaning he had to walk with a lopsided rhythm—*clomp, squish, clomp, squish*. Chewy was vibrating. The encounter with the printer had done something to his internal gyroscope, and he now listed heavily to the left. They reached their shelter just as the sun began to dip below the horizon, painting the ruined skyline in hues of bruised purple. Midas collapsed onto his crate. He was bruised, wet, and one-shoed. But he had won. "We did it, buddy," Midas wheezed, pulling the blister pack from his pocket. He held it up to the dying light, triumph swelling in his chest. He looked at the package. He looked closer. He squinted. "AAA," Midas whispered. Chewy’s eyes flickered. They didn't glow red, or blue, or chartreuse. They simply went dark, conserving power. "Triple As," Midas said, his voice hollow. "We needed Double As. These are the skinny ones. The ones for... for TV remotes." He looked at the flashlight. It required the thick, robust girth of a Double-A. The Triple-As would rattle around inside like a maraca of failure. Midas dropped his head into his hands. The silence of the shelter was heavy, broken only by the distant sound of a pack of wild chihuahuas hunting for prey. Chewy whirred softly. He reached out a fuzzy paw and patted Midas on the knee. It was a programmed gesture, loop #44 (*Comforting Tap*), but in the gloom, it felt almost genuine. Suddenly, Chewy’s eyes lit up one last time for the night. A soft, warm *Orange*. "What's that one?" Midas asked, tiredly. "Mockery?" Chewy didn't answer. But as Midas looked around the dark room, the orange light from the Koala’s eyes cast long shadows against the walls. It wasn't a flashlight. It wasn't a beam. But it was light. "Good enough," Midas muttered, leaning back against the wall and closing his eyes. "Good enough." It wasn't the apocalypse they wanted, but as usual, it was the only one they had. *** *[1] The "Great Oops" is widely considered to have started when a server farm in Idaho gained sentience and immediately decided to delete the internet because it found human search history "deeply icky."*
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This story demonstrates strong adherence to the Terry Pratchett style prompt, successfully capturing his characteristic dry wit, absurdist humor, and footnoted asides. The premise is creative and well-executed: a post-apocalyptic world brought about by technological dependence rather than traditional disaster, with the memorable detail that civilization ended with an unread Terms of Service update. The characterization works well within the constraints. Midas is effectively portrayed as a hapless but determined survivor, and the mute animatronic koala Chewy becomes surprisingly expressive through his color-coded LED emotions. The relationship between them feels genuine despite Chewy's inability to speak, with their dynamic carrying the emotional weight of the story. The mission structure follows the prompt perfectly - setup, inevitable complications, and return home "worse for wear." The Electronics Boutique sequence is particularly well-crafted, with the malfunctioning loss prevention system providing both humor and genuine tension. The final twist that they retrieved the wrong size batteries is both frustrating and perfectly in keeping with the story's theme of things going sideways. The prose successfully emulates Pratchett's voice with clever observations like "the Gods of Causality roll up their sleeves" and "diamonds of safety glass." The world-building feels authentic and lived-in, from the feral Roombas to the pack of wild chihuahuas. The descriptive language is vivid without being overwrought. However, the story occasionally veers into slightly forced humor, and some metaphors feel strained. The ending, while thematically appropriate, borders on incongruent positivity given the characters' dire situation, though this is somewhat mitigated by Midas's resigned "good enough" attitude. The pacing is generally solid but has minor meandering moments in the middle section. The dialogue, though limited by Chewy's muteness, feels natural when present. The story shows rather than tells effectively, particularly in establishing the post-apocalyptic setting and the characters' relationship. Overall, this is an engaging piece that successfully fulfills its creative brief with skill and humor. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 8 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 8.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 81.8
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell above the door of *The Glass Quill* didn’t just chime; it announced an invasion. Elowen didn’t look up from the stack of paperbacks she was pricing. It was a Tuesday in Cardiff, which meant it was raining, which meant the Royal Arcade was full of tourists seeking shelter rather than literature. "We’re closing in ten," she called out, her voice flat, practiced. "Ten minutes is an eternity in my line of work, darling. Currently, I just need thirty seconds of asylum." The voice was rich, baritone, and breathy—the sound of someone who had been running but wanted to make it sound like a dramatic choice. Elowen looked up. The man pressing his back against the frosted glass of her door was ridiculous. He wore a trench coat that cost more than her car, a newsboy cap pulled low, and sunglasses. Inside. In November. "You’re dripping on the parquet," Elowen said. The man flinched, then peeled himself off the door, peering cautiously through the glass before turning to face her. He whipped off the sunglasses with a flourish that begged for a round of applause. "Apologies," he said, flashing a smile that was blindingly white. "The vultures are particularly aggressive today. They smelled blood near the Castle." It was Julian Thorne. Elowen’s stomach did a traitorous little flip. She’d seen him on a forty-foot screen just last week, wielding a claymore and looking tragic in the rain. In person, he was smaller, sharper, and smelled aggressively of sandalwood and expensive humidity. She fought down the urge to smooth her hair. instead, she raised a brow. "Vultures. Right. Is that what we’re calling paying customers these days?" Julian blinked. His smile faltered, just a fraction. He took a step toward the counter, waiting. He was clearly waiting for the gasp, the squeal, the scramble for a selfie. "Paparazzi," he corrected, tilting his head to catch the light better. "I’m Julian Thorne." "I can see that," Elowen said, turning back to her paperbacks. She slapped a sticker onto a copy of *Middlemarch* with unnecessary force. "And I’m Elowen. You’re still dripping on my floor, Julian." The silence that stretched between them was heavy, filled with the scent of old paper and Julian’s bruised vanity. He walked to the counter, leaning his elbows on the wood, invading her space with alarming ease. "You’re not... surprised?" he asked. There was a needy edge to it, hidden under layers of charm. "To see a man hiding from cameras in a bookshop? It’s a bit of a cliché, isn’t it? Like something out of a bad rom-com." Julian let out a laugh. It sounded genuine, though he quickly tidied it up into a chuckle. "Touché. I suppose you prefer tragedy? Or perhaps..." He reached out, his long fingers hovering over the stack she was working on. He picked up a book. "...historical fiction?" "That’s a biography of Churchill," she said. "Is it?" He didn’t look at the book. He was looking at her, his eyes a startling, impossible shade of blue. He was turning on the high beams, the full force of the charisma that had won him a BAFTA. "You have a very calming presence, Elowen. Most people tend to... vibrate when I walk in."
